awd_titl_txt: TWC: Small: Collaborative: Towards Agile and Privacy-Preserving Cloud Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
Cloud computing offers many benefits to users, including increased availability and flexibility of resources, and efficiency of equipment. However, privacy concerns are becoming a major barrier to users transitioning to cloud computing. The privilege design of existing cloud platforms creates great challenges in ensuring the trustworthiness of cloud by granting too much power to the cloud administrators, who could launch serious insider attacks by abusing the administrative privileges.

This project uses a well-understood philosophy, separation-of-privilege, in the architectural design of a cloud platform. The architectural design and the strong homomorphic cryptographic approach protect data privacy in cloud environments from different angles. This project develops an innovative privacy-driven architectural design, with one focus on the privilege-level design of each software component of a cloud platform, and another on defending insider attacks. This project investigates new mechanisms to de-privilege the cloud administrator and enable more fine grained access control among the software components of a cloud platform. More specifically, the new mechanisms enable agile configuration of the platform; user-configurable privacy protection; and strong isolation in the user space.  The techniques developed under this project are immensely important as users place more of their data into the cloud and rely upon cloud providers to keep that data private.

por.por_cntn:
With a focus on developing innovative trustworthy execution environments for applications that make use of sensitive data, this project has three main outcomes. (1) Through collaborative research, we have developed MyCloud, an innovative light-weight hypervisor which prevents corrupted insiders from stealing tenants? private data while enabling applications to access their private data as usual in cloud data centers. A unique feature of MyCloud is that it reduces the TCB (trusted computing base) size to less than 10,000 lines of code. (2) Through collaborative research, we have developed TrustShadow, a new kind of Trustworthy Execution Environments (TEEs) for unmodified applications running on mobile devices (e.g. smartphones) and Internet of Things devices. In contrast to the previous TEEs which rely on a secure operating system (OS), TrustShadow is essentially a lightweight hardware-assisted runtime system. Being lightweight makes TrustShadow very suitable for resource-constrained devices. We have shared the source code of TrustShadow with a security company in Silicon Valley and are in the process of releasing the source code to the public.  (3) We have developed CryptMe, a novel memory encryption technique. It is motivated by the fact that conventional memory encryption techniques cannot deal with misuse of legitimate OS functions.  CryptMe combines conventional memory encryption and hardware-assisted memory access controls, resulting in a new kind of memory encryption which can defeat both physical attacks and misuse of legitimate OS functions.  (4) Besides the three main outcomes, we have also developed a major extension of TrustShadow. The extended TrustShadow runtime system further employs a page-based encryption mechanism to ensure that all the data segments of a security-critical application appear in ciphertext in the DRAM chip. Whenever an encrypted data page is accessed, it is transparently decrypted to a page in the internal RAM, which is immune to physical attacks.   (5) Through this project, two post-docs and five graduate students have received rigorous research training.

Modified by: Peng Liu
